text: Family Member: But say if his rib spots start- causing him pain - Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Family Member: Can they go in specifically with a proton or? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Would it be needed, a proton be needed, or can regular radiation take care of it? Doctor: So typically it’s just regular radiation. So right now as far as I’m aware it’s sort of like isolated rib treatment for proton is not commonplace. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we don’t, I don’t think that’s part of their indication. text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: That has enough specificity that it’s a glue to the antibody. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh so what they usually do is uh you go there. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And as we discussed before, this is generally considered a little bit controversial. It’s not the standard therapy. So if you read a textbook about managing advanced prostate cancer it would only say that you’d give Abiraterone you’d also give an injectable suppression at the same time like Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: However, as I told you before, I have used Abiraterone (Zytiga) Patient: Yes, I have also, and I think I was zero point something for over a year. Doctor: Yeah, about point one. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yes, so again, with the caveat that it would be considered unconventional therapy – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - you know given that caveat if we both acknowledge that, I would be willing to consider that for you, especially if the studies don’t show any disease or metastatic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: disease is one. And if we were both informed that this is really not the conventional therapy and yet you still want to or agree to do it. But I think as long as it’s an informed decision, I’m willing to consider that.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
